Moldova issues security warning on Russi.title: Moldova issues security warning on Russia-controlled region
Moldova issues security warning on Russi.summary:
By EUobserverMoldova's pro-Western president Maria Sandu warned Tuesday some "forces inside Transnistria" were in "favour of war", referring to the country's Russia-controlled breakaway region.
Sandu spoke after emergency meetings following explosions and rocket attacks in Transnistria Monday and Tuesday, as well as belligerent statements by Russian politicians and generals.
Moldova, like Ukraine, used to be a Soviet vassal, but recently applied to join the European Union.
Moldova issues security warning on Russi.text:
By EUobserver

Moldova's pro-Western president Maria Sandu warned Tuesday some "forces inside Transnistria" were in "favour of war", referring to the country's Russia-controlled breakaway region. Sandu spoke after emergency meetings following explosions and rocket attacks in Transnistria Monday and Tuesday, as well as belligerent statements by Russian politicians and generals. Moldova, like Ukraine, used to be a Soviet vassal, but recently applied to join the European Union.

EU agriculture commissioner to visit Lat.title: EU agriculture commissioner to visit Latvia on Tuesday
EU agriculture commissioner to visit Lat.summary:
RIGA - The European Union's (EU) Commissioner for Agriculture, Janusz Wojciechowski, is due to visit Latvia this Tuesday, LETA was told at the Latvian Agriculture Ministry.
On Tuesday morning, the EU commissioner will meet with Agriculture Minister Kaspars Gerhards (National Alliance).
Their meeting is expected to focus on the situation in the Latvian and European agricultural sector in the wake of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Later, Commissioner Wojciechowski and Gerhards will meet with representatives of Latvian agricultural NGOs.
In the afternoon, the EU commissioner and the Latvian minister will visit the Vaidelotes farm in Code parish, Bauska municipality, and the Rudeni farm in Sesava parish, Jelgava municipality.
EU agriculture commissioner to visit Lat.text:
RIGA - The European Union's (EU) Commissioner for Agriculture, Janusz Wojciechowski, is due to visit Latvia this Tuesday, LETA was told at the Latvian Agriculture Ministry.

On Tuesday morning, the EU commissioner will meet with Agriculture Minister Kaspars Gerhards (National Alliance). Their meeting is expected to focus on the situation in the Latvian and European agricultural sector in the wake of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The officials will also discuss the European Commission's commentaries to Latvia on the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) Strategic Plan from 2023.

As LETA was told at the Agriculture Ministry, Gerhards said earlier that following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the content of EU member states' national CAP strategies must be regarded in the context of the new geopolitical situation and brought in line with the long-term goals of the EU and its member states, as well as the new challenges facing the world.

Later, Commissioner Wojciechowski and Gerhards will meet with representatives of Latvian agricultural NGOs.

In the afternoon, the EU commissioner and the Latvian minister will visit the Vaidelotes farm in Code parish, Bauska municipality, and the Rudeni farm in Sesava parish, Jelgava municipality.

Marking Earth Day, the officials will plant linden trees in the historical park of Lielplatone Manor in Jelgava municipality.

Security headquarters in Moldova's break.title: Security headquarters in Moldova's breakaway region hit by explosions
Security headquarters in Moldova's break.summary:
A series of explosions struck the building housing the ministry of state security in Moldova’s breakaway region of Transnistria on Monday (25 April), days after Moscow said the Russian-backed region could be drawn into the war in Ukraine.
State security HQ in Transnistria targeted in a hit-and-run rocket propelled grenade attack, a source in Tiraspol tells me.
The statelet, which is controlled by pro-Russian separatists and hosts Russian troop bases and arms depots, borders western Ukraine.
Moscow is planning to seize Ukraine’s south and open a route to Moldova’s Transnistria region, as part of the “second phase” of its military operation, Russia’s Central Military District (CFD) command said last week.
Ukrainian officials, meanwhile, have warned Russia could potentially use the region to launch attacks into western Ukraine.
Security headquarters in Moldova's break.text:
A series of explosions struck the building housing the ministry of state security in Moldova’s breakaway region of Transnistria on Monday (25 April), days after Moscow said the Russian-backed region could be drawn into the war in Ukraine.

Officials from the breakaway region’s interior ministry said the building had been fired on by unknown assailants with grenade launchers, TSV television station reported, showing a picture of a grenade launcher abandoned at the scene.

The TV station showed the windows and doors of the building in Tiraspol blown out, with fire crews shown at the scene.

State security HQ in Transnistria targeted in a hit-and-run rocket propelled grenade attack, a source in Tiraspol tells me. Transnistria is a pro-Russia, self-declared republic in Moldova with a long border with Ukraine. There are about 1,500 Russian troops stationed there. pic.twitter.com/fN4Msmy4Lz — Simon Ostrovsky (@SimonOstrovsky) April 25, 2022

According to a statement by Transnistria’s government and local media reports, there were no reports of casualties.

Transnistria, which demanded recognition of independence earlier in March, is considered under international law to be part of Moldova.

The statelet, which is controlled by pro-Russian separatists and hosts Russian troop bases and arms depots, borders western Ukraine.

Moldova’s government said it was “concerned about the incident”, which it said was aimed at creating tensions in a region it had no control of.

“The aim of today’s incident is to create pretexts for straining the security situation in the Transnistrian region, which is not controlled by the constitutional authorities,” the statement said.

In the past weeks, Russian forces have advanced to cut off Ukraine’s access to the sea – a move interpreted by Western military experts as an attempt to create a land corridor from Russia-controlled Donbas, over Crimea to Transnistria.

Russian general says Moscow aim is to leave Ukraine as a landlocked country A Russian general declared on that Moscow wants to seize all of southern and eastern Ukraine, as it presses on with a new offensive after its campaign to capture the capital Kyiv collapsed last month.

Moscow is planning to seize Ukraine’s south and open a route to Moldova’s Transnistria region, as part of the “second phase” of its military operation, Russia’s Central Military District (CFD) command said last week.

“Control over the south of Ukraine is another way out to Trans-Dniester,” Rustam Minnekayev, acting commander of the CFD, said in a statement carried by TASS and Interfax.

Minnekayev then claimed there was evidence of “oppression” of the Russian-speaking population there, an allegation Russia has previously used in relation to claims of oppression of Russian minorities in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions in eastern Ukraine as grounds for military action.

Ukrainian officials, meanwhile, have warned Russia could potentially use the region to launch attacks into western Ukraine.

“Our working assumption is that Moldova is not a target for military action and [we] see no reason why we would be attacked,” the country’s foreign minister Nicu Popescu told EURACTIV last month.

“At the same time, we as a government have a duty to be preparing for the full spectrum of scenarios – and that, of course, includes negative scenarios,” he said.

Moldova puts its hope in EU membership, although it has not followed Ukraine and Georgia in demanding NATO accession. Most of Moldovans speak Romanian and Russian, and reportedly half of them have obtained Romanian passports.

(Edited by Georgi Gotev)

Ukraine wants from Bulgaria Weapons and.title: Ukraine wants from Bulgaria Weapons and Support for its EU membership
Ukraine wants from Bulgaria Weapons and.summary:
Ukraine wants Bulgaria to provide weapons and support for the country's EU membership.
This was stated by the Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine Olha Stefanishyna before the forum "EU meets the Balkans", which is being held today in Sofia.
Stefanishyna said in a video message that authorities in Kyiv would request weapons from the Bulgarian delegation, which is due to arrive in the Ukrainian capital tomorrow.
Bulgaria expects the European Commission to make a recommendation as soon as possible to grant Ukraine the status of a candidate country for EU membership, Bulgarian Foreign Minister Teodora Genchovska said during the forum.
Follow Novinite.com on Twitter and FacebookWrite to us at editors@novinite.comИнформирайте се на Български - Novinite.bg/BNR
Ukraine wants from Bulgaria Weapons and.text:
Ukraine wants Bulgaria to provide weapons and support for the country's EU membership. This was stated by the Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine Olha Stefanishyna before the forum "EU meets the Balkans", which is being held today in Sofia.

Stefanishyna said in a video message that authorities in Kyiv would request weapons from the Bulgarian delegation, which is due to arrive in the Ukrainian capital tomorrow.

Bulgaria expects the European Commission to make a recommendation as soon as possible to grant Ukraine the status of a candidate country for EU membership, Bulgarian Foreign Minister Teodora Genchovska said during the forum.

Genchovska said Russia was violating international law and had no guarantee that international order would be maintained:

"The methods of war and cruelty against the Ukrainian population, against children, women, are trying to really forcefully limit the right of an independent state to determine its future, its foreign and security policy. Responsibility for this war weighs on the shoulders of Russia".

Write to us at editors@novinite.com

Информирайте се на Български - Novinite.bg

/BNR

Russia gas giant Gazprom to cut off pipe.title: Russia gas giant Gazprom to cut off pipelines to ‘unfriendly' Poland and Bulgaria
Russia gas giant Gazprom to cut off pipe.summary:
Russian state gas giant Gazprom has said it will stop supplying natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria over their refusal to pay in Russian roubles.
The Polish state oil and gas company PGNiG said it had been informed that deliveries through the Yamal-Europe pipeline will be severed from Wednesday morning.
Gazprom also informed Bulgarian state gas company Bulgargaz that it will halt gas supplies as of Wednesday, state energy officials said.
Poland receives around nine billion cubic metres of gas from Russia every year.
He had threatened to cut gas supplies in case the demands were not fully met.
Russia gas giant Gazprom to cut off pipe.text:
Russian state gas giant Gazprom has said it will stop supplying natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria over their refusal to pay in Russian roubles.

The Polish state oil and gas company PGNiG said it had been informed that deliveries through the Yamal-Europe pipeline will be severed from Wednesday morning.

Gazprom also informed Bulgarian state gas company Bulgargaz that it will halt gas supplies as of Wednesday, state energy officials said.

Poland receives around nine billion cubic metres of gas from Russia every year.

However, Poland’s climate minister Anna Moskwa insisted “there will be no shortage of gas in Polish homes” due to the move, noting the nation’s gas storage facilities were at 76 per cent capacity.

She added: “Appropriate diversification strategies that we have introduced allow us to feel on the safe side in this situation.”

Bulgaria, which is almost completely dependent on Russia for its annual consumption of about three billion cubic metres of gas, said it had “have undertaken steps for alternative agreements for natural gas deliveries and for coping with the current situation”.

“At present, there is no need for (imposing) any restrictive measures on consumption,” officials said.

But increased demand for non-Russian gas sources may push up prices across the continent, worsening an ongoing energy crisis.

Russian President Vladimir Putin said last month that he would require “unfriendly” foreign nations to pay for their gas in roubles instead of dollars and euros, overriding existing contracts, in a bid to solve his nation’s economic crisis.

He had threatened to cut gas supplies in case the demands were not fully met.

Poland has repeatedly said it would not comply with the new scheme of gas payments. It has also said it would not extend a contract with Gazprom, which expires at the end of the year.

The list of “unfriendly” countries includes nearly all of Europe, encompassing the entirety of the European Union, as well as non-EU states Albania, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.

Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova and Serbia were the only European states not on the list.
